Yet it is easy to calculate the
degree of moral & intellectual improvement
-ment which the world would have
exhibited, had they never lived. A
greater degree little more nonsense
wd. have been talked for a century or
two; & perhaps a few more men
women & children burnt as heretics.
We might not at this moment have been
congratulating each other on the abolition
of the Inquisition in Spain. But
all
it exceeds the imagination to concieve
what would have been the actual
moral
condition of the world, if neither Dante
Petrarch Boccaccio, Chaucer Shakespeare
Calderon, Lord Bacon, nor Milton had
ever existed: if Raphael & Michael
Angelo had never been born, if the
Hebrew poetry had never been translated;
if a revival of a study of Greek
literature had never taken place; if
